stream_context.summary: Kaze works almost the entire stream on the "cowboy" world’s underground Monty-Mole hideout.  He codes, debugs and play-tests a multi-mole boss encounter, shows a brand-new custom collision engine and discusses overall project status.

development_findings.summary: Kaze finished Stars 1 & 2 for the mole hideout and says only 3 main courses, 2 side levels and 1 Bowser stage remain – about 80 % of the game.
development_findings.quote: We’re like 80 % of the way there – three more main courses and two side levels and one Bowser level.

development_findings.summary: A new collision system completely replaces Mario 64’s original code, eliminating most sticking issues and BLJ spots (though he hopes some BLJs remain).
development_findings.quote: I made a completely new collision system.  I said, ‘fuck Mario 64’s collision.’  It is unusable.  We have our completely own collision system now and it’s so much more stable.

development_findings.summary: Monty Mole boss design: 5–9 moles pop from randomized holes around Mario, throw rocks that always target Mario’s current position (non-predictive), and can be defeated by jumping on them; each drops 1–2 coins.  After all are beaten the star spawns.
development_findings.quote: We’ll have them pop out, throw a rock, and whenever you hit one there’s one less but the rest go faster.

development_findings.summary: Implemented physics math to guarantee rocks land on Mario’s position; minimum velocity added so throws reach Mario even if elevation is small.
development_findings.quote: It shoots exactly where Mario is at.  It’s not predictive; I don’t want this to be predictive.

development_findings.summary: Memory limits forced him to disable bridge collision temporarily in the cowboy level.
development_findings.quote: I had to remove the collision here for RAM reasons for now.

development_findings.summary: Design philosophy on bugs: keep exploits that require intentional setup (e.g., BLJ) but remove glitches players can trigger accidentally.
development_findings.quote: If there’s a bug you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I’ll leave it in.  But if it can happen on accident, I’ll remove it.

development_findings.summary: Uses ChatGPT for quick formula look-ups but still hand-derives solutions when the AI fails.
development_findings.quote: ChatGPT is not being useful here; let’s just make up bullshit until it works.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is on a fitness ‘cut’, lost ~15 lbs in 40 days, feels ‘chiseled’ and talks about personal body image.
context_findings.quote: I’m around 40 days into my cut right now. I lost around 15 pounds and I’m starting to look fucking chiseled.

context_findings.summary: He values freedom over nostalgia; dislikes high-school memories because of lack of autonomy.
context_findings.quote: If you want freedom you need a job and money and stuff, and you just don’t get that in school.

context_findings.summary: Critique philosophy: he ignores surface comments and tries to interpret the feeling behind feedback rather than literal suggestions.
context_findings.quote: Whenever I receive criticism I try to figure out what the person was feeling that’s wrong, not what they’re saying.

context_findings.summary: Plans to launch a Kickstarter for an original 3-D platformer once Return to Yoshi’s Island is released, possibly hiring other ROM-hackers.
context_findings.quote: Alongside the release… I’ll probably launch a Kickstarter for my own game and then transition to working on that.

context_findings.summary: Discusses sponsorship experiences: Brilliant paid fairly; Raid offered more; a Chinese handheld company became angry at his unconventional ad.
context_findings.quote: You’re offering me a $150 device to upload to my main channel where an ad usually gets $3,000 – yeah, no way.

zeina.summary: Zeina is not home during the stream; Kaze jokes she ‘banned’ him from shaving his head.
zeina.quote: If it wasn’t for my wife banning me from going bald I would’ve already shaved.

key_stories.title: Rewriting the Collision System
key_stories.summary: Fed up with Mario 64’s unreliable collision, Kaze wrote an entirely new engine that prevents sticking and works even in extreme geometry.  It unintentionally removed most BLJ spots, prompting discussion on which glitches to keep.
key_stories.challenge: Mario 64 collision caused players to snag on complex geometry and limited new level designs.
key_stories.process: Kaze coded a fresh collision routine, stress-tested it in tight spaces and showcased improvements live.
key_stories.outcome: Stable movement in cramped areas; BLJ mostly gone, requiring possible deliberate re-addition.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at this – we could go into a shit thing like this and not get stuck.  It literally just works.

key_stories.title: Designing the Monty Mole Boss
key_stories.summary: During the stream Kaze prototypes a boss where multiple Monty Moles pop out of holes and hurl rocks.  He iterates on math for rock trajectories, timing, coin drops and star placement.
key_stories.challenge: Create a memorable boss fight that teaches the rock-dodging mechanic without feeling cluttered.
key_stories.process: Uses ChatGPT for formulas, then hand-derives; tests different mole counts, velocities, randomness and coin rewards.
key_stories.outcome: Settles on 5–9 moles with randomized holes, minimum throw velocity and 1–2 coin drops; star appears after last mole.
key_stories.key_quote: We’ll just do nine moles here; bonk them all to win – I think that works just fine.

key_stories.title: The Sponsor Ad Fiasco
key_stories.summary: Kaze accepted a free Chinese handheld for review but produced an unconventional ad that joked about scams.  The company expected main-channel exposure and became angry.
key_stories.challenge: Balance honesty with sponsor expectations while maintaining creative voice.
key_stories.process: He created a comedic ad, posted it on a smaller channel and ignored follow-up emails when the sponsor complained.
key_stories.outcome: Sponsor upset, no lawsuit; Kaze retains creative integrity and warns about undervaluing ad space.
key_stories.key_quote: I think I gave them an awesome ad – they were so mad at me.
